ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A better understanding of the Japanese language

This semester seemed big on the speeches and presentations, so I definitely spoke Japanese a lot more and this probably helped with my pronunciation. We also learned grammar at a much quicker pace towards the end because the new textbook seemed to move much faster than the old one, but we got to learn a lot about Japanese culture too.
I learned about Japanese culture and how to speak the language.
Reading, writing, speaking, and listening in Japanese. The upper level textbook will also focus on knowledge about Japan and learning Kanji vocabulary.
Learned Japanese Vocab, Grammar, and Kanji. Learned a lot about Japanese culture. Much practice speaking, listening, and writing Japanese, and enhanced my presentation skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Overall course structure is very unclear. Requirement for additional assignment, such as speeches and presentation, were frequently changed by the instructor and often become contradictory.

The homework is a bit more I think. I understand learning a language needs a lot of practice but this is a little repetitive.
Other than that, the course is awesome.
The course is very well organized with daily and weekly schedules listing out exactly what will happen every class. There is also a lot of presentations to practice speaking.

Sometimes the pace was too fast, but for the most part it was well paced and set up well for student learning. The structure of the grammars and the class made picking up on new topics and ideas easy and gave us plenty of opportunities to practice.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I found it to be the same difficulty as JAPN 130

I would never recommend this course to other student due to its poorly organized structure, constantly changing requirements and instructor that did not respect students response and failed to provide helpful comments. Students were forced to hand in drafts while the instructor does not even go through them.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to continue learning Japanese. It is a class that is fast-paced and requires you to spend some time on almost every day, but being able to communicate better in Japanese, write more complex sentences, and read longer texts makes it worth it. We also got to talk to Japanese college students (via Zoom) for a few weeks, which I found really fun and eye-opening.
Yes because it was really fun. I also learned a lot of new Japanese grammar structures and also about a lot of Japanese culture. It really helped me improve my Japanese.
Yes, if you want to learn Japanese and Japanese culture. Note that this is a 1.5 credit course with a lot of homework and tests are graded rather strictly.
